title: Breadth-First Search (BFS)
summary: Level-by-level graph traversal using a queue

sections.title: Intuition
sections.contentMarkdown:
Breadth-First Search explores a graph **level by level**, like ripples expanding outward from a stone dropped in water. Starting from a source node, BFS visits all neighbors at distance 1, then all neighbors at distance 2, and so on.

Think of it as exploring a maze by checking all paths that are 1 step away, then all paths that are 2 steps away, systematically ensuring you find the shortest path to any reachable location.

**Key characteristic**: BFS uses a **queue** (First-In-First-Out) to track which nodes to explore next, ensuring level-order traversal.

sections.title: Time & Space Complexity
sections.contentMarkdown:
**Time Complexity**: O(V + E)
- Visit each vertex once: O(V)
- Explore each edge once: O(E)
- Combined: O(V + E)

**Space Complexity**: O(V)
- Queue can hold up to O(V) nodes
- Visited set stores O(V) nodes
- Where V = number of vertices, E = number of edges

sections.title: When to Use BFS
sections.contentMarkdown:
✅ **Use BFS when:**
- Finding the **shortest path** in an unweighted graph
- Level-order traversal is needed
- Exploring neighbors before going deeper
- Finding all nodes within k distance
- Solving puzzles with minimum moves (e.g., chess knight, word ladder)

❌ **Don't use BFS when:**
- Graph is very wide (many neighbors per node) - high memory usage
- Depth-first exploration is more natural for the problem
- Only need to check if path exists (DFS is simpler)

sections.title: Variations & Related Algorithms
sections.contentMarkdown:
**Bidirectional BFS**: Start from both source and target, meet in the middle

**Multi-source BFS**: Start BFS from multiple sources simultaneously

**0-1 BFS**: Variant for graphs with 0 and 1 edge weights using deque

**Dijkstra's Algorithm**: Weighted version of BFS using priority queue
